docs.lead_paragraph: When establishing the Victim Compensation Fund last year, Congress foresaw a potential legal nightmare. It thus imposed one condition before victims of the Sept. 11 attacks could receive money from the fund: They had to waive their right to sue anyone except the terrorists. But recent claims suggest that Congress did not go far enough. It should reconsider whether lawsuits arising over the events of Sept. 11, other than those against the terrorists, should be allowed at all. Last week, lawyers for one of the firms hardest hit by the attacks, Cantor Fitzgerald, issued a report claiming that the planned allocations of the fund are contrary to law. The family of a young trader should be given $5 million for lost income, they argue, not $3 million. The decision by the fund's special master, Kenneth Feinberg, to give every family an additional $250,000 for pain and suffering, they say, is ''woefully inadequate.''

headline.main: Facing the Limits of Law, and of Lawsuits

docs.abstract: Philip K Howard Op-Ed article argues that Congress should reconsider whether lawusits arising over events of Sept 11, other than those against the terrorists, should be allowed at all, noting there is no logical limit to lawsuits that have been brought already, with claims amounting to many billions of dollars; contends it is beyond capacity of litigation to produce a just or fair result; suggests that perhaps greatest cost of allowing these claims, as we teeter on edge of decades of litigation, is to fabric of our culture; holds recriminations are potentially endless (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The HealthSouth Corporation, acknowledging that it is being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission, sought yesterday to quell increasing concerns over its Medicare billing practices and stock sales by its chairman. In a conference call with investors and analysts, officials of the company, the nation's largest chain of rehabilitation hospitals, said that its businesses were fundamentally sound, and they outlined the steps being taken to restore confidence in management.

byline.original: By REED ABELSON with MILT FREUDENHEIM

docs.lead_paragraph: For 23 years, Felix Batista rode the elevator up 106 floors to work as a member of the wait staff at the Windows on the World restaurant. On Sept. 11, everything changed. Mr. Batista was on vacation with his family, and that decision saved his life. That day, he lost 73 coworkers and his job. While the first anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks has come and gone, in New York the needs born out of that tragedy remain. Each step that we take -- whether it is investing $20.9 billion for cleanup and recovery or financing programs to track the health of rescue workers and volunteers at ground zero -- will bring New York closer to recovery.

docs.lead_paragraph: Democrats in the House, backed by two Republican senators, began an effort today to force Republican leaders to schedule a vote on a bill that would accelerate the approval and marketing of generic drugs. The Senate passed the bill 78 to 21 on July 31. House Republican leaders have said they see no reason to take it up because it would undermine the patent rights of brand-name companies. Moreover, they say, the House has already passed a bill that addresses the cost of drugs, by providing Medicare coverage of prescriptions for 40 million elderly and disabled people. The Senate has voted down several proposals to provide such benefits under Medicare.

docs.lead_paragraph: A scheduled strike by 3,000 home health aides in the New York area was averted yesterday when their employer, Premier Home Health Care Services, reached a tentative settlement with the health care union 1199/S.E.I.U. The union had planned to begin a three-day strike yesterday, which would have created huge strains on Premier and some 2,000 clients who need aides because they are chronically ill or were recently released from hospitals.

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna, the large managed-health-care company, said yesterday that Microsoft, one of its largest accounts, was dropping its health plans to switch to the nonprofit Premera Blue Cross. An Aetna spokeswoman, Wendy Morphew, confirmed that Microsoft had taken its business to Premera Blue Cross, which has announced plans to go public. Premera is one of the biggest insurers in Washington State. Aetna, formerly the No. 1 health insurer by enrollment, is trying to turn itself around after posting losses and making acquisitions that were widely viewed as missteps.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Cigna Corporation, a leading health insurer in the United States, said yesterday that it had received approval to enter the life insurance market in China. The company, based in Philadelphia, said the China Insurance Regulatory Commission had told it it could set up operations. Cigna is considering forming a joint venture with a local company and expects to begin life insurance operations next year in Shenzhen, Guangdong Province. Cigna and other companies are heading for China to tap a market with more than one billion people and a growing middle class, which is expected to begin buying life insurance and retirement savings products. Cigna's international operations account for about $1 billion of its $19 billion in revenue.

Suozzi delivered his $2.3 billion budget proposal for 2003 today, his fellow Democrats on the Nassau County Legislature endorsed it as a solution to the county's fiscal crisis. ''Yes, he's got his 10 votes,'' said the Legislature's presiding officer, Judith A. Jacobs, referring to the party's majority in the 19-member body. But at the same time, the Republican minority leader, Peter J. Schmitt, attacked the proposal as a tax-and-spend program.
